conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the 0 to 10-second interval is greater than 100 meters or less than 100 meters, we can use the velocity-time graph provided.
The graph shows the velocity v (in meters per second) of the skydiver as a function of time t (in seconds).
The area under the graph between two points in time represents the distance traveled during that interval.
From t = 0 to t = 10 seconds, the skydiver's velocity increases from 0 to 20 m/s.

premise: To find the distance fallen during this interval, we need to calculate the area under the curve from t = 0 to t = 10.
conclusion: The area under the curve can be approximated by calculating the area of a triangle.
The base of the triangle is the time interval, which is 10 seconds.
The height of the triangle is the final velocity, which is 20 m/s.

premise: Area of the triangle = 1/2 × base × height.
The area under the curve is exactly 100 square meters.
conclusion: The distance fallen during the 0 to 10-second interval is exactly 100 meters.
